description: From cumulate +‎ -ive. Compare also French cumulatif, Italian cumulativo and Spanish cumulativo.

adjectives.description: cumulative (comparative more cumulative, superlative most cumulative)

entries.meaning: Incorporating all current and previous data up to the present or at the time of measuring or collating.

definitionGroups.group: That is formed by an accumulation of successive additions.

examples: cumulative conjunctions like and, both…and and as well as

entries.meaning: (finance) Having priority rights to receive a dividend that accrue until paid.
(law) (of evidence, witnesses, etc.) Intended to illustrate an argument that has already been demonstrated excessively.
examples: The state wants to bring in ten blood-spatter experts to testify. Your Honor, that is cumulative testimony.
